snippet: A federal judge in a case involving the possession of crack cocaine explains why the jury remains a guardian of fairness in sentencing.
abstract: Editorial commends decision by Federal District Judge William Young to sentence Rodney Gurley to 30 months in jail for possession of crack cocaine, rather than the mandatory minimum of 10 years, based on the jury's findings; asserts that Judge Young is right to prioritize the jury's constitutional role in sentencing over federal sentencing guidelines and mandatory minimums to ensure that criminal laws are applied fairly.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in a case involving the possession of crack cocaine explains why the jury remains a guardian of fairness in sentencing.

headline.seo: A Jury Draws a Line on Sentencing
